user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
```c
void OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;
    int                             os_flags;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    os_flags = fcntl(impl->fd, F_GETFL);
    if (os_flags == -1)
    {
        /* No recourse if F_GETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
        OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_GETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    else
    {
        os_flags |= OS_IMPL_SOCKET_FLAGS;
        if (fcntl(impl->fd, F_SETFL, os_flags) == -1)
        {
            /* No recourse if F_SETFL fails - just report the error and move on. */
            OS_DEBUG("fcntl(F_SETFL): %s\n", strerror(errno));
        }
    }

    impl->selectable = true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragments in OS_SetSocketDefaultFlags_Impl are provably unreachable. Explanation: 
- The conditional branches depend on the runtime return value of fcntl; both the (os_flags == -1) branch and the else branch (and the nested F_SETFL error handling) can be executed depending on the result of the system calls, so neither branch is statically unreachable. 
- The final statement impl->selectable = true; is executed unconditionally at the end of the function and is therefore reachable. 
- The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expands to an array lookup using the token index; although misuse of the token could cause undefined behavior at runtime, that does not make any code statically unreachable. 
- The OS_DEBUG macro is defined empty; its removals are compile-time elisions of debugging calls, not unreachable code paths left behind. 
Given the above, there are no code fragments here that should be flagged for MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
